Line 15: Line 15:
For his early education, Gamal Mubarak attended [[St. George's College, Cairo]] before entering the [[American University in Cairo]]. He graduated with a [[Business]] Degree from the university and he claims he also earned an [[MBA]] from the school.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} He began his professional life working for [[Bank of America]]. He worked primarily in the field of [[investment banking]].
For his early education, Gamal Mubarak attended [[St. George's College, Cairo]] before entering the [[American University in Cairo]]. He graduated with a [[Business]] Degree from the university and he claims he also earned an [[MBA]] from the school.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} He began his professional life working for [[Bank of America]]. He worked primarily in the field of [[investment banking]].
â
With a few colleagues, Mubarak left Bank of America to set up London-based [[Medinvest Associates Ltd]], which manages a [[private equity fund]], and to do some corporate finance consultancy work.<ref>http://www.winne.com/topinterviews/gamal.htm</ref> His role with Medinvest has since ended.'''
+
With a few colleagues, Mubarak left Bank of America to set up London-based [[Medinvest Associates Ltd]], which manages a [[private equity fund]], and to do some corporate finance consultancy work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winne.com/topinterviews/gamal.htm |title=Interview with MR. GAMAL MUBARAK Hairman Of Medinvest Associates Ltd |publisher=Winne.com |date=1999-01-14 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref> His role with Medinvest has since ended.'''
â
Mubarak is also the [[Chairman]] of the Future Generation Foundation (FGF), an NGO dedicated to job training, and an honorary member of the [[Rotary International|Rotary]], which was awarded to him in May 2000 by then Rotary International president Frank Devlyn.<ref>http://www.frankdevlyn.org/galleries/Egypt/egypt6.jpg</ref>
+
Mubarak is also the [[Chairman]] of the Future Generation Foundation (FGF), an NGO dedicated to job training, and an honorary member of the [[Rotary International|Rotary]], which was awarded to him in May 2000 by then Rotary International president Frank Devlyn.<ref>[http://www.frankdevlyn.org/galleries/Egypt/egypt6.jpg ]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
In May 2007, Mubarak married Khadija El Gammal, the daughter of Egyptian businessman Mahmoud El Gammal. They have a daughter, Farida, who was born in 2010.
In May 2007, Mubarak married Khadija El Gammal, the daughter of Egyptian businessman Mahmoud El Gammal. They have a daughter, Farida, who was born in 2010.
Line 28: Line 28:
The grooming of Gamal Mubarak to be his father's successor as the next president of Egypt became increasingly evident at around the year 2000.<ref>Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73–88</ref> With no vice-president, and with no heir-apparent in sight, Gamal started enjoying considerable attention in the Egyptian media.<ref>Brownlee, Jason (2008) [https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf "The Heir Apparency of Gamal Mubarak"] ''Arab Studies Journal'' pp. 36–56</ref> [[Bashar al-Asad]]'s rise to power in [[Syria]] in June 2000 just hours after [[Hafez al-Asad]]'s death, sparked a heated debate in the Egyptian press regarding the prospects for a similar scenario occurring in Cairo.<ref>Sobelman, Daniel (2001) [http://www.meforum.org/27/gamal-mubarak-president-of-egypt "Gamal Mubarak, President of Egypt?"] ''Middle East Quarterly'' 8(2): pp. 31–40</ref>
The grooming of Gamal Mubarak to be his father's successor as the next president of Egypt became increasingly evident at around the year 2000.<ref>Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73–88</ref> With no vice-president, and with no heir-apparent in sight, Gamal started enjoying considerable attention in the Egyptian media.<ref>Brownlee, Jason (2008) [https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf "The Heir Apparency of Gamal Mubarak"] ''Arab Studies Journal'' pp. 36–56</ref> [[Bashar al-Asad]]'s rise to power in [[Syria]] in June 2000 just hours after [[Hafez al-Asad]]'s death, sparked a heated debate in the Egyptian press regarding the prospects for a similar scenario occurring in Cairo.<ref>Sobelman, Daniel (2001) [http://www.meforum.org/27/gamal-mubarak-president-of-egypt "Gamal Mubarak, President of Egypt?"] ''Middle East Quarterly'' 8(2): pp. 31–40</ref>
â
Both President Mubarak and his son denied the possibility of any inheritance of power in Egypt, although this was widely speculated. Most recently, this claim was made in early 2006, when Gamal Mubarak declared repeatedly that he has no aspiration to succeed his father, but that he will maintain his position in the NDP as deputy secretary general, a post he holds in addition to heading the party's policy committee, probably the most important organ of the NDP.<ref>[http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096 http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096] <font color="blue">deadlink, 9 November 2010</font></ref>
+
Both President Mubarak and his son denied the possibility of any inheritance of power in Egypt, although this was widely speculated. Most recently, this claim was made in early 2006, when Gamal Mubarak declared repeatedly that he has no aspiration to succeed his father, but that he will maintain his position in the NDP as deputy secretary general, a post he holds in addition to heading the party's policy committee, probably the most important organ of the NDP.<ref>[http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096 http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096] <span style="color:blue;">deadlink, 9 November 2010</span></ref>
â
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>[http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm]<font color="blue">deadlink, 9 November 2010</font></ref>
+
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>[http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm]<span style="color:blue;">deadlink, 9 November 2010</span></ref>
On February 26, 2005, Mubarak ordered the constitution changed to allow multi-candidate presidential elections before September 2005 by asking parliament to amend Article 76 of the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]]. This change in the constitution is seen by some analysts as a ploy to seamlessly allow Gamal Mubarak to inherit the top position in Egypt. According to this view, Gamal Mubarak would be one of the candidates in a presidential elections and would be supported by the ruling party and the government-controlled media. Since remaining serious candidates would be disqualified by the NDP-controlled People's Assembly leaving only the less popular candidates, the inheritance of power would be accomplished through a "democratic" process.
On February 26, 2005, Mubarak ordered the constitution changed to allow multi-candidate presidential elections before September 2005 by asking parliament to amend Article 76 of the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]]. This change in the constitution is seen by some analysts as a ploy to seamlessly allow Gamal Mubarak to inherit the top position in Egypt. According to this view, Gamal Mubarak would be one of the candidates in a presidential elections and would be supported by the ruling party and the government-controlled media. Since remaining serious candidates would be disqualified by the NDP-controlled People's Assembly leaving only the less popular candidates, the inheritance of power would be accomplished through a "democratic" process.
â
Following the commencement of the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]], [[Omar Suleiman]] was appointed the vice-president of Egypt on January 29, 2011.<ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/uk-egypt-suleiman-idUKTRE70S2JL20110129 Omar Suleiman, new Egyptian vice-president</ref> Suleiman announced on 3 February 2011 that Gamal Mubarak would not seek election.
+
Following the commencement of the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]], [[Omar Suleiman]] was appointed the vice-president of Egypt on January 29, 2011.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/uk-egypt-suleiman-idUKTRE70S2JL20110129 Omar Suleiman, new Egyptian vice-president]</ref> Suleiman announced on 3 February 2011 that Gamal Mubarak would not seek election.
== Role in the ouster of his father, Hosni Mubarak ==
== Role in the ouster of his father, Hosni Mubarak ==
â
Political analysts<ref>http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/02/13/108650/egypt-insider-mubaraks-fall-was.html</ref> speculate that the alleged detoriorating state of the Egyptian economy in the last days of [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s rule was caused by Gamal and his friends taking over as a political advisors to Mubarak. He isolated his father from the people, and pushed his own agenda, and his ailing father didn't listen to anyone but him. He is also reported to have had his businessmen friends take governmental positions and ministries, implementing policies that benefitted him and his friends.<ref>http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/02/13/108650/egypt-insider-mubaraks-fall-was.html</ref>
+
Political analysts<ref name="mcclatchydc1">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/02/13/108650/egypt-insider-mubaraks-fall-was.html |title=Egypt insider: Mubarak's fall was years in the making | McClatchy |publisher=Mcclatchydc.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref> speculate that the alleged detoriorating state of the Egyptian economy in the last days of [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s rule was caused by Gamal and his friends taking over as a political advisors to Mubarak. He isolated his father from the people, and pushed his own agenda, and his ailing father didn't listen to anyone but him. He is also reported to have had his businessmen friends take governmental positions and ministries, implementing policies that benefitted him and his friends.<ref name="mcclatchydc1"/>
â
[[Reuters]] Africa reports of a fight taking place between him and his older brother, [[Alaa Mubarak]]. Alaa supposedly accused him of ruining his father's last days, and humiliating him.<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71C0HQ20110213</ref>
+
[[Reuters]] Africa reports of a fight taking place between him and his older brother, [[Alaa Mubarak]]. Alaa supposedly accused him of ruining his father's last days, and humiliating him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71C0HQ20110213 |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows-paper | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=2011-02-13 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>
== Allegations of Corruption ==
== Allegations of Corruption ==
â
Following the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, media sources started to point to the financial dealings of Gamal Mubarak, which were described as suspicious. On 28 February 2011 the Egyptian daily [[Al-Ahram]] published a list of bank accounts allegedly belonging to Gamal Mubarak. Alahram reported that the Chief Prosecutor of Egypt received a report that Gamal Mubarak inexplicably amassed significant sums of money that were deposited in these accounts. This allegations came on background of a decision from the Prosecutor General of Egypt to freeze all bank accounts belonging to the Mubarak family, including Gamal Mubarak.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/457/2011/02/28/25/64884.aspx</ref> The Egyptian Appeals Court ordered that Mubarak's financial status is reviewed by the court on March 5, 2011. It is expected that the court will render a decision in that hearing whether or not to uphold the decision to freeze Mubarak's assets.<ref>http://dostor.org/crime/11/february/28/37187</ref>
+
Following the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, media sources started to point to the financial dealings of Gamal Mubarak, which were described as suspicious. On 28 February 2011 the Egyptian daily [[Al-Ahram]] published a list of bank accounts allegedly belonging to Gamal Mubarak. Alahram reported that the Chief Prosecutor of Egypt received a report that Gamal Mubarak inexplicably amassed significant sums of money that were deposited in these accounts. This allegations came on background of a decision from the Prosecutor General of Egypt to freeze all bank accounts belonging to the Mubarak family, including Gamal Mubarak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/457/2011/02/28/25/64884.aspx |title=Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø³Ø±ÙØ© ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¦ÙØ© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¨ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© 147ÙÙÙÙÙ Ø¯ÙÙØ§Ø± ÙØ³ÙØ²Ø§Ù Ù200 ÙÙÙÙÙ ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref> The Egyptian Appeals Court ordered that Mubarak's financial status is reviewed by the court on March 5, 2011. It is expected that the court will render a decision in that hearing whether or not to uphold the decision to freeze Mubarak's assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/february/28/37187 |title=5ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ Ø£ÙÙÙ Ø¬ÙØ³Ø§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ¸Ø± ÙÙ ØªØ¬ÙÙØ¯ Ø£Ø±ØµØ¯Ø© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù..Ù26ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø±Ø´ÙØ¯ ÙØ¹Ø² ÙØ¹Ø³Ù | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>
